abstract: City budget cuts are forcing the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service to eliminate a program for formerly homeless families, the only service of its kind in the borough.   Donna A. Santarsiero, the executive director, said the program will end in June unless the Brooklyn Bureau receives enough private donations to keep it going.

abstract: A Christmas night encounter in 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The New York Times, was moved to help an impoverished immigrant, inspired the creation of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund has helped immigrants ever since. In what remains a city of immigrants, the fund's 85th annual appeal is under way. The money  raised goes to seven agencies that aid needy New Yorkers -- immigrant and native-born alike. The stories of some beneficiaries, from Ukraine, Cuba and Georgia, are told here today.    Articles, page 65.
lead_paragraph: A Christmas night encounter in 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The New York Times, was moved to help an impoverished immigrant, inspired the creation of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund has helped immigrants ever since. In what remains a city of immigrants, the fund's 85th annual appeal is under way. The money raised goes to seven agencies that aid needy New Yorkers -- immigrant and native-born alike. The stories of some beneficiaries, from Ukraine, Cuba and Georgia, are told here today.

abstract: In a city where nearly 5,500 families began the year as residents of public shelters, homelessness is a problem that sits uneasily on the conscience of even the most hard-hearted New Yorker. To bring some measure of comfort to the heatless and homeless, they have been giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helps finance social services for new immigrants to New York City (S)
snippet: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helps finance social services for new immigrants to New York City (S)
lead_paragraph: Immigrants have been helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since its inception. Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The Times, began the fund after encountering a pauper, an immigrant, on Christmas night in 1911. Mr. Ochs believed that if readers of his newspaper knew how some of their neighbors lived, they would want to help. So the next year, a reporter searched the files of social service agencies to write about the city's 100 neediest cases. They included an Armenian immigrant who suffered from leprosy and the widow and four children of an Italian immigrant who had died of tuberculosis and who all suffered from the disease. The fund's 85th annual appeal, now under way, runs through Feb. 28. The Times pays all administrative expenses so donations can go directly to services for people who need them. And those who need them, officials of social service agencies say, are increasingly going to be immigrants affected by the new Federal welfare law, which sharply restricts Government assistance for noncitizens, among others. More than two million immigrants live in New York City today, and traditionally, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has noted, immigrants are among its hardest workers. ''Those tenement scenes of the Lower East Side were in fact a thriving and prosperous population; they were just packed in,'' he said. ''Emma Lazarus, wherever she is in heaven, has a lot to account for. They weren't the wretched refuse of anybody's shores. They come here to work.'' And work, as they so often find, is not easy to come by. Here are some of their stories.

headline.main: City of Immigrants, Pausing, Offers A Belated Welcome
headline.print_headline: City of Immigrants, Pausing, Offers A Belated Welcome

And on each tab are words in gold lettering that represent landmarks in the lives of Ms. Garcia and Mr. Blue: 1 week drug free, 6 weeks drug free, 6 months drug free, 1 year drug free.

abstract: Concerned by a poor election turnout in low-income neighborhoods, the Community Service Society of New York has worked for 10 years to register voters and educate them about local issues.   The society's 10-year-old Voter Participation Project has registered more than 140,000 voters in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan, including 21,000 in the last two years. The project works with community organizations in each borough, training residents in get-out-the-vote techniques and providing workshops in grass-roots lobbying. In election years, the project also sponsors candidates forums in poor neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Concerned by a poor election turnout in low-income neighborhoods, the Community Service Society of New York has worked for 10 years to register voters and educate them about local issues.

lead_paragraph: Mary Anderson tugged on the strap of Kiarra Boodram’s helmet, making sure it was secure, then pushed Kiarra’s wheelchair up to Hot Diggity, a white pony three and a half feet tall with gray and black patches.

abstract: Julio Angarita, 59, is aware of the flaws in his apartment in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, but he is still happy to call it home.
snippet: Julio Angarita, 59, is aware of the flaws in his apartment in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, but he is still happy to call it home.
lead_paragraph: The floor is uneven and the stove does not work. Nor does the electricity in the kitchen. Until it was fixed eight months ago, there had been a gaping hole in the ceiling for three years. Julio Angarita, 59, is aware of the flaws in his apartment in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, but he is still happy to call it home.

lead_paragraph: Two weeks before her son Elias was to graduate from Intermediate School 218 in Washington Heights, Ana Corporan was still not sure she would be able to see him walk across the stage with his classmates to receive his diploma.

lead_paragraph: Hallway photos in Teisha Waterman’s Brooklyn apartment show her identical twin sons, Pharaoh and Phallon, dressed alike. They are both smiling, cute as two matching buttons.

abstract: Two Syrian refugees scraped to get by with their daughter in Lebanon. But when they took out a loan that they couldn’t repay after the blaze, their situation worsened.

lead_paragraph: HALBA, Lebanon — In her three-room apartment here, Fatima al-Ewy yearned for her old life in Syria.
